image.altText: A generic photo of ASX board.

items.synopsis: Global markets fall sharply and Australian stocks lose more than 1 per cent at the open, while expectations remain that the US Federal Reserve may not be finished hiking interest rates. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Falls across ASX as China woes hit Wall St, European stocks

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The Reserve Bank of New Zealand has left its official cash rate on hold at 5.5 per cent. After an aggressive hiking cycle that took rates to a 14-year high, the central bank has now sat on its hands since May's rate rise. Here's what the RBNZ monetary policy committee had to say about the decision: The current level of interest rates is constraining spending and hence inflation pressure, as anticipated and required. The Committee agreed that the [official cash rate] needs to stay at restrictive levels for the foreseeable future to ensure annual consumer price inflation returns to the 1 to 3% target range, while supporting maximum sustainable employment. The New Zealand economy is evolving broadly as anticipated. Activity continues to slow in parts of the economy that are more sensitive to interest rates. Labour shortages are easing as overall demand softens and immigration adds to labour resources. Headline inflation and inflation expectations have declined, but measures of core inflation remain too high. NZ's annual inflation rate declined to 6 per cent in the June quarter, while its unemployment rate is at 3.6 per cent.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: NZ rates on hold for another month

children.content: The
Reserve Bank of New Zealand
has left its official
cash rate on hold at 5.5 per cent
After an aggressive hiking cycle that took rates to a 14-year high, the central bank has now sat on its hands since May's rate rise.
Here's what the RBNZ monetary policy committee had to say about the decision:

The current level of interest rates is constraining spending and hence inflation pressure, as anticipated and required. The Committee agreed that the [official cash rate] needs to stay at restrictive levels for the foreseeable future to ensure annual consumer price inflation returns to the 1 to 3% target range, while supporting maximum sustainable employment.

The New Zealand economy is evolving broadly as anticipated. Activity continues to slow in parts of the economy that are more sensitive to interest rates. Labour shortages are easing as overall demand softens and immigration adds to labour resources. Headline inflation and inflation expectations have declined, but measures of core inflation remain too high.
NZ's annual inflation rate declined to 6 per cent in the June quarter, while its unemployment rate is at 3.6 per cent.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Not a good start for the Australian stock market, with the ASX 200 down more than 1 per cent just a quarter of an hour into the session. And with 175 of the top 200 stocks in the red, it's fair to say the losses are broad-based. Here's how the sectors are faring so far: Looking at other markets around the region, South Korea's Kospi has lost 0.9 per cent since its session began a short time ago, while Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dropped by the same amount on the open. The NZ 50 is 0.7 per cent weaker.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX sheds more than 1 per cent in early trade

children.content: Not a good start for the Australian stock market, with
the ASX 200 down more than 1 per cent
just a quarter of an hour into the session.
And with
175 of the top 200 stocks in the red
, it's fair to say the losses are broad-based.
Here's how the sectors are faring so far:
ASX 200 sectors on Weds morning
(Refinitiv)
Looking at other markets around the region, South Korea's
Kospi

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: While residential real estate may have been on the bounce over the past five or six months, rising interest rates have made property a bad sector to be in over the past year. Developer and landlord Mirvac has swung to a $165 million loss in financial year 2023, down from a $906 million profit the year before. The loss has been driven by write-downs in the value of its office (-5.6 per cent ) and retail (-5.3 per cent ) property portfolios, partly offset by a +6.2 per cent revaluation of its industrial properties. The company also sold off about $500 million of "non-core" assets at a 2 per cent discount to their book values, excluding the cost of the sales. Mirvac said it would continue to increase its exposure to residential and industrial real estate, while reducing the share of office space on its books, as the persistence of working from home dents demand in that sector. Excluding one-off costs, the company's "operating profit" dropped 3 per cent to $580 million. It will pay a 5.3 cent per share final dividend .
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Mirvac highlights that property was not the place to be over the past year

Mirvac has swung to a $165 million loss
in financial year 2023, down from a $906 million profit the year before.
The loss has been driven by

per cent
) and retail (-5.3
per cent
) property portfolios

a +6.2 per cent revaluation of its industrial properties
The company also sold off about $500 million of "non-core" assets at a 2 per cent discount to their book values, excluding the cost of the sales.

Excluding one-off costs, the company's
"operating profit" dropped 3 per cent to $580 million
It will pay a
5.3 cent per share final dividend
